p: In Spain, according to data from the Spanish Forest Map [ 13, 14], the distribution area of most of the species being studied is considerable. The largest surface area is covered by C. ladanifer (1.7 Mha), followed by P. pinaster (1.35 Mha), R. officinalis (1.3 Mha), P. sylvestris (1.25 Mha), E. globulus (625,000 ha), J. communis (60,000 ha), and finally, E. nitens, with 12,000 ha. The surface area of E. nitens may be larger since it is a species that is commonly used in new wood production plantations in northern Spain.
